result.execSummary:
The defendant Patrick R Blachut was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Theft-False Representation>$5000-$10,000, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation>$5000-$10,000, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation>$5000-$10,000, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation>$5000-$10,000, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
While incarcerated 25% of the inmate funds shall be applied to outstanding financial obligations.  
Not eligible for programs till after 2 years
Consecutive to: to Counts 1 thru 3

superMiscConds.notes:
Counseling deemed necessary
Maintain full time employment
Do not enter any casino
Submit to DNA testing
Own no weapons

supervisions.notes:
If probation or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Consecutive to: to Cts. 1 thru 3

records.addlTxt: 2:30 p.m.  Defendant Patrick R Blachut in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery.  Craig Lambert appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Atty. Lambert has no corrections to PSI.  Atty. Slattery wishes that this hearing be adjourned today to review some other records.  Atty. Lambert opposes the adjournment.  Coiurt denies the motion for continuence.  Atty. Slattery has no corrections to the PSI and is ready to proceed.  Atty. Lambert argues for his commendation.   Atty. Slattery argues for his recommendation.  Court orders his sentence.

ADDRESS INFO for Patrick R Blachut
Current: 950 E 7th St, Port Edwards, WI 54469 United States  (Effective: 06-03-2015)
Prior: 505 S Peach, Marshfield, WI 54449 United States
Sentencing hearing at 08-06-2015 02:30 pm

Defendant Patrick R Blachut in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery.  Craig Lambert appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Atty Slattery request a PSI. Court orders a PSI. Bond continued  Sentencing hearing scheduled for August 6, 2015 at 02:30 pm.
Jury trial - 12 person at 05-27-2015 08:30 am
Exhibit 1

Defendant Patrick R Blachut in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery.  Craig Lambert appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Jason Parks is sworn and testifies to being a detective with the Marshfield Police Dept.  Testifies to the ticket scam involving the defendant. Testifies to talking with the defendant about the tickets he said he could buy and what happened to the money he had received from people to purchase those tickets.  The witness testifies that he concluded the the defendant would not have been able to purchase the tickets.  Jason identifies the defendant as Patrick Blachut, Court recognizes.  Exhbit 1 is entered and received.  Testifies to when these alleged incidents happened.  Atty. Slattery cross examines.  Testifies to how it became apparent that the defendant could not obtain the tickets.  Arguments from Atty. Slattery.  Probable Cause Found.  Bond continued  Pre-trial conference scheduled for May 8, 2015 at 09:00 am.
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on March 26, 2015 at 11:00 am.
